image.altText: Two people walk past a steel sign reflecting in the sunlight that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: All eyes are on the RBA today, where the central bank board is widely expected to cut interest rates for the first time since 2020. Follow live.

title.children: RBA set to cut interest rates for the first time since 2020

image.altText: Group of city workers walking on street

props.synopsis: After more than six months of on-again off-again signals, interest rates are about to start a descent. But even with inflation on the mend, the cost-of-living crisis is nowhere near being solved.

title.children: Why the Reserve Bank has little option but to cut interest rates

image.altText: Birdseye view of a young girl drawing at a table.

props.synopsis: National test results show just 28 per cent of Year 10 students are proficient in civics.

title.children: Call for 'immediate' curriculum overhaul after 'shocking' civics results

image.altText: A man holds a woman's head and kisses her.

props.synopsis: A Foreign Correspondent investigation has detailed the decades of sexism and misogyny leading up to the infamous World Cup kiss.

title.children: Infamous World Cup kiss blew lid on open secret in women's football

image.altText: Pippa Buchanan shows the battery that lives in her shed.

props.synopsis: Households are handing over control of their solar systems in exchange for equipment. Experts believe virtual power plants could play a vital part in our future energy system as the grid struggles to cope with excess solar.

title.children: Households slash power bills by turning into modern power plants

image.altText: A plane flipped on its roof, with several people pictured nearby. It is surrounded by snow.

props.synopsis: Multiple people have been injured after a commercial flight crashed at an airport in Toronto, Canada, with the plane eventually coming to rest upside down.

title.children: Three people critical after plane flips at Canadian airport

image.altText: Jenkins looks directly at the camera sadly wearing camo gear and a hoodie

props.synopsis: The short video was posted to YouTube just over a week ago and shows the 32-year-old Australian dressed in green army fatigues.

title.children: 'I would like more freedom': New video of Oscar Jenkins emerges

image.altText: french president macron stands in paris next to a french guard who is saluting

props.synopsis: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said "a US security guarantee is the only way to effectively deter Russia from attacking Ukraine again".

title.children: Europe needs a 'US backstop' to ensure lasting peace in Ukraine

image.altText: The back of the head of a man wearing a cap and glasses, sitting outside. His face cannot be seen.

props.synopsis: Experts and families are warning that the current system to intervene and rehabilitate people who have joined extremist groups is flawed.

title.children: Chris fears his brother may carry out a 'lone wolf attack'. He's pleading for help

image.altText: Kyneton Football and Netball Club players in a huddle

props.synopsis: Kyneton Football and Netball Club's women's team decided to break away from the club in the wake of what players describe as a "horrible, volatile environment".

title.children: 'Broke our hearts': Why Kyneton's women's side left their club

image.altText: Peter Dutton and Anthony Albanese's faces are overlaid onto a blue and red pie graph. Logos of social media companies present

props.synopsis: The election has not been been called yet but the battle for votes on social media is already well underway. So which party is ahead?

title.children: TikTok is crucial for Gen Z voters and the PM is losing the battle

image.altText: The police running sheet and poster relating to the missing Beaumont children.

props.synopsis: This weekend, another search for the remains of the Beaumont children will be undertaken at a former foundry site in Adelaide's west. For almost 60 years, the disappearance of nine-year-old Jane, seven-year-old Arnna and four-year-old Grant has baffled detectives.

title.children: Disappearance of Beaumont children 'fundamentally changed society'

image.altText: An image of street lights in Dili, Timor-Leste.

props.synopsis: A high-stakes legal battle spanning nearly a decade sees Australian energy company Lighthouse Corporation suing Timor-Leste for $523 million, while the nation hits back with explosive fraud allegations.

title.children: Timor-Leste calls $523m Australian lawsuit 'major fraud'

image.altText: GFX 5 Tasmania North West fires

props.synopsis: The bushfires on Tasmania's west coast have now burned nearly 95,000 hectares in hard-to-access terrain. Here's how that compares to the devastating fires of 2018-19 — and what comes next.

title.children: Five maps to help you visualise Tasmania's massive wilderness fires

image.altText: A varroa mite on a honey bee standing on honeycomb.

props.synopsis: While honey producers and beekeepers have ways to treat varroa-infested hives, the bees themselves also have a few tricks up their sleeve.

title.children: Varroa is spreading through Australia, but some bees can fight back

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: A young woman wearing a black dress with tubes attached to an IV drip gives the peace sign

props.synopsis: Young people are more than twice as likely to get forms of bowel cancer than older Australians were at the same age, and researchers have a few clues as to why.

title.children: Why are so many young people getting diagnosed with bowel cancer?

image.altText: Person displays something in their hand.

props.synopsis: Something has washed up on a Tasmanian beach over the weekend. The Bob Brown Foundation has sounded alarm bells but the salmon farming company it is targeting is reassuring locals there is nothing to worry about.

title.children: Salmon producer orders tests after 'chunks' wash up on Tasmanian beach

image.altText: A blackened window with insulation exposed.

props.synopsis: Detectives investigating a fire that killed a 27-year-old woman at Truganina in January believe the arson attack is linked to Victoria's tobacco wars. The woman is not believed to be involved in the dispute.

title.children: Fatal house fire in Melbourne linked to tobacco wars

image.altText: Shane Patton is well-lit in a side profile photograph against a dark backdrdop.

props.synopsis: After a whirlwind of headlines saw the state's top cop vacate the chair, Victorians might be asking themselves: did Jacinta Allan's government throw Shane Patton under the bus?

title.children: Behind the scenes, tensions around Victoria's top cop had been brewing

image.altText: Gas leak at Nord Stream 2 as seen from the Danish F-16 interceptor.

props.synopsis: Experts say the use of sabotage as a weapon of war could become more common, after a spike in mysterious incidents across Europe since the beginning of the Ukraine War.

title.children: 'Brave new world' in warfare due to snapped cables, putting Australia at risk

image.altText: A roadside sign against coal mining on farmland.

props.synopsis: Kepco bought up large swathes of the New South Wales Bylong Valley with plans to build a coal mine. The mine was knocked back years ago, but the company still isn't saying what comes next.

title.children: South Korean energy company silent on plans for rural NSW town

image.altText: sign with hedge behind

props.synopsis: The messages were circulated on the instant messaging platform Snapchat by students from Presbyterian Ladies' College.

title.children: Elite WA school condemns racism after students caught sending 'disgusting' messages

image.altText: Pope Francis sitting on a white chair during a service.

props.synopsis: The Vatican says the pontiff will remain in hospital "as long as needed" as he battles a respiratory tract infection.

title.children: Pope Francis to stay in hospital amid 'complex clinical situation'

image.altText: A woman with long hair, smiling.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's proposed trade tariffs on Canada are on pause but, should the US president reinstate them, Canada's trade minister warns the US will pay.

title.children: 'Respond with impact': Canadian trade minister issues Trump tariff warning

image.altText: A sleek wooden desk with the Qantas logo above it.

props.synopsis: A review of disclosures from state parliamentarians' register of interests show a string of former ALP ministers have lost their designations as members of the elite Qantas Chairman's Lounge while new ministers have gained access.

title.children: Qld LNP ministers get Qantas Chairman's Lounge access as Labor MPs lose out

image.altText: woman looks at phone while laying on couch

props.synopsis: Ever feel like your downtime is constantly interrupted by other tasks niggling away at you? Frequently jumping from task to task is called time confetti, and while it might sound cute, it isn't great for productivity or our wellbeing.

title.children: Understanding 'time confetti' and how it's stealing your downtime

image.altText: Bruising on Elaf's arm and leg in the aftermath of the incident.

props.synopsis: A childcare worker is afraid to leave her home alone after being one of two women attacked at Epping Plaza, prompting advocacy groups to call for immediate action amid a rise in Islamophobic incidents.

title.children: 'Don't feel safe': Two women attacked at shopping centre as Islamophobia spikes

image.altText: Mussels under the sea on a reef

props.synopsis: Scuba divers in a NSW marine park claim reefs are overwhelmed with mussels, sparking plans for genetic testing to work out if the wild and farmed stock are linked.

title.children: Jervis Bay farm accused of causing mussel population 'explosion'

image.altText: A dark silhouette of a hand holding a mobile phone showing a purple DeepSeek logo and loading screen in front of a Chinese flag

props.synopsis: Most commentators say Chinese-owned AI chatbot DeepSeek performs just as well as the market-leader ChatGPT, but should we be wary of it?

title.children: ABC News Daily: Is China's DeepSeek riskier than ChatGPT?

image.altText: Three people lie in adjacent sections of a bus that each have a mattress in them.

props.synopsis: Fundraisers feel ripped off after backing the Sleepbus charity that they thought would deliver buses and give homeless people a decent night's sleep.

title.children: Project to give homeless a safe sleeping space running out of money

image.altText: Antisemitic graffiti incident at a home in Maroubra

props.synopsis: The government says the legislation is designed to crack down "on the really unacceptable spate of escalating and troubling graffiti, racial hatred and antisemitism".

title.children: New hate speech laws tackling antisemitism come before parliament today

image.altText: Workers on the roof of a construction site, with the Perth skyline in the background.

props.synopsis: Perth was last year declared Australia's least affordable to rent in, and now the government has launched an election pitch geared around getting more long-term rental stock. Here's how it works.

title.children: Could WA's proposed build-to-rent push change the game for renters?

image.altText: A sign on a country road warning of floodwater ahead.

props.synopsis: Residents in flood-affected parts of northern Queensland have enjoyed a brief dry spell, but isolated heavy rainfall could hamper recovery efforts.

title.children: Heavy, isolated rainfall forecast for flood-ravaged North Queensland

image.altText: Madeleine Sami stands smiling in front of a white wall

props.synopsis: Madeleine Sami on what we can expect from season two of the NZ queer IVF comedy Double Parked, and when we can expect Deadloch's return.

title.children: Impostor syndrome never ends, just ask Double Parked's Madeleine Sami
